course.subject: ELEC
course.name: Linear-System Theory
course.description: Introduces modern system theory, with applications to control, signal processing and related topics.  Basic system concepts, state-space and I/O representation, properties of linear systems, controllability, observability, minimality, transfer-function matrices, state and output feedback, stability, observers, optimal regulators.

reviews.author: nor
reviews.title: Good and knowledgeable course
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers 2 parts in this semester:
Matrix Analysis
Linear System Theory

Matrix analysis part talks about all matrix stuff, it expands (nearly every question) into multi-dimensional sense.
Linear system theory uses the knowledge from matrix analysis, and talks more about control, but again in matrices.

At the beginning, Prof Qiu set up a questionnaire to ask students' preference so that he can adapt the teaching content accordingly. It is very considerable, although the teaching proportion of these 2 parts are still 50%-50%, as before.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is great. I had very few prerequisite knowledge for this course, but can still catch up most of the points.

In some weeks, the course was run in a face-to-face mode. Prof Qiu wrote things on board precisely and he would like to have some interactions with students.
The most challenging part of his teaching is the proofs. Sometimes he assumed most students knew the prerequisite knowledge and asked us to go through after class. But unfortunately I was not one of those students so it could cause me a big headache.

Anyway, it is still a good course, and I learned a lot of useful knowledge.
reviews.comment_grading:
Due to COVID-19, there is no exams. Instead, we have assignments and a final project:

6 assignments (released per fortnight): 50%
Final project: 50%

Assignments are just questions randomly picked from lecture notes, and the project requires extra reading materials so that we can explain the new ideas based on the knowledge we had both from this course and the materials.

Finally, got A+. The grading is really nice.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload of assignment is high.
At the beginning, I can finish only one question within a whole night, but there were 5-6 questions in each assignment. That was really a suffering time and I started to doubt my IQ.
But almost every question is doable. Sometimes the questions cannot be worked out directly from seeing lecture notes, and these certainly require extra research on the internet.

The project took 2-3 days to prepare and record. It is fine after a whole semester's studying.

reviews.author: Beck_Sisyphus
reviews.title: Great starting grad school class with Prof. Shi
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Shi is young and challenging. There are two teachers who are in charge of Linear system theory, Prof. SHI, Ling and Prof. QU, Li, and I would prefer Prof. Shi for his enthusiasm.
reviews.comment_grading: Prof. Shi has high expectation. He expects you have read the materials thoroughly, and get a starting point before class.
reviews.comment_workload: This class is hard. If you started the class from a fresh graduated Electrical engineering, you will be challenged by the mathematical heavy load from the matrix theory and proof.

reviews.author: Weilong
reviews.comment_content: This course involves Introduces modern system theory, with applications to control, signal processing and related topics. Basic system concepts, state-space and I/O representation, properties of linear systems, controllability, observability, minimality, transfer-function matrices, state and output feedback, stability, observers, optimal regulators.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. QIU has a profound foundation in control theory. His teaching is clear and informative. But he takes too much time in the matirx theory and little time in control theory.
reviews.comment_grading: It is easy to get a A-, but it takes more efforts to get a A / A+.
reviews.comment_workload: There are around 5 homeworks and 1 final project. Not hard at all.

reviews.author: Spartan
reviews.title: A very theoretical yet solid exploration into linear system theory
reviews.comment_content: The whole course be divided into two parts: the first part is about matrix theory, and the second part will elaborate on fundamental linear system theory.
reviews.comment_teaching: The matrix is the key to control system. As an expert in the field, Prof. Qiu absolutely knows how to teach in a sensible and solid manner. He is very rigorous and explain everything clearly with appropritate and intuitive example. Every students who pay attention to his course and do the hws diligently will surely learn a lot.
reviews.comment_grading: I heard the grading is overally okay, but getting a A+ is definitely not an easy thing.
reviews.comment_workload: Prof. Qiu gives hard problems. So it might take you fare amount of time to work on the assignments unless you are a genius in math.

reviews.author: etkf
reviews.title: Challenging but rewarding
reviews.comment_content: The content is pretty standard for graduate level linear algebra + control system.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Qiu is absolutely an expert in this field (obviously) and he can explains most concept clearly. Even if you cannot understand any part right away, you are most welcome and encouraged to ask even if it is simple questions. Although sometimes he may forget a small part of what he intended to teach, or made some minor algebraic/computation mistakes (which coincidentally provided us the chances to test whether we actually understood the content).
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is very good. I was only about 30-50% sure about each question in midterm and final (and the marks were both below 60/100) and I still got an A. Although I heard A+ is pretty hard to get but A range shouldn't be a problem.
reviews.comment_workload:
The minimum workload can be very light, if you just want to pass.
But in order to do well, you need to spend a lot of time to practice on questions in related area and sometimes even some weird ones (e.g. the "extra credit assignment"). That is, unless you are super super smart.

reviews.author: mzhnq
reviews.title: a fine course
reviews.comment_content: Content is good, covering a wide range of knowledges on algebra, some are advanced and hard to understand without enough background.
reviews.comment_teaching: Overall it is good, but the background is not explained enough so this deteriorates the overall understanding of the course material.
reviews.comment_grading: the grading is not harsh. You can get reasonably good grade even if there are half of the questions in the exams you are not sure of or don't know how to answer.
reviews.comment_workload: Several homeworks and exams, no project, but the homeworks are hard to do without external help. If doing by oneself, it takes much effort, since there are many derivations and questions asking for proving theories and lemmas.
